summary:
As a teacher I have to be able to explain things clearly and positively, both verbally and in writing. Good communication skills are some of the simplest, most essential tools for teaching. 
Open hands, good eye contact, smiling, good posture, respect for othersâ€™ personal space: these are all part of good communication. Having good body language establishes trust and means students will not only have more confidence in you, but will want to listen to and work with you. 
By using three languages confidently, I become better at observing my surroundings and adept at focusing on relevant information and editing out the irrelevant. I tend to make more rational decisions. Because any language contains nuance and subtle implications in its vocabulary, and these biases can subconsciously influence my judgment. Good language means that my diction is clear and audible, my sentences are concise, my thought processes are logical and my delivery is flowing.

A natural sceintist loves to explain things. The ability to explain things clearly and effectively can help the scientist to become a good teacher. This teacher is like a candle - it consumes itself to light the way for others but passing on knowledge, interests and challenges to the next generation of undergraduates is a rewarding outcome.

KBBL is a company that issues;  health certificates for food industry, environmental files for business, accreditation for farms 
I have joined the new born department (knowledge center) which is a group of scientist and consultants in different fields of science. My field cosmetic is to work for an industrial client on the subjects of quality control, GMP and validation. The other part of the job is to issue a TIF (technical information file) for a product and its raw materials. The TIF includes all the chemical, microbiological and toxicological information according to the European Union guidelines and its amendments for pharmaceutical and cosmetics industry. It is a complusary legal and technical file for any product produced in the EU.', 'title': 'Quality control adviser', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 166740, 'name': 'Universiteit Utrecht', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C510BAQG6HfmPTdJKXw/company-logo_400_400/0/1519884681258?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=i09IbD7RibJlZYVNrl7o5pIy-Ip7_0I2XZqXZA9kXUI', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/universiteit-utrecht/', 'employees': {'start': 5001, 'end': 10000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2003}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2005}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Utrecht Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2003}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2005}}, 'company': 'Utrecht University', 'description': 'A PhD proposal
The aim of the proposal
The aim is to monitor the redox processes of epithelial cells in the gut (as a first model) to find out the mechanistic details and to what extent the oxidative damage affects the cellular membranes. The plan is to synthesize specific probes that will target to particular cellular components, both in terms of cellular localization as with respect to the chemical target (protein and/or lipid). The aim is also to focus on early cellular responses, i.e. before cells become apoptotic. Once the goal is reached to specifically follow redox processes in the epithelial cells, finally, specific antioxidants will be identified. (The proposal is not granted the financial aid)', 'title': 'Research Scientist', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 4081, 'name': 'University of Amsterdam', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4E0BAQEfHBj_we-_kw/company-logo_400_400/0/1659945104460?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=k8egLWP3eIqIloLFULSmlLPZQR7cvpzTKHpzgtnWaBI', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/university-of-amsterdam/', 'employees': {'start': 1001, 'end': 5000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2002}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2003}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2002}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2003}}, 'company': 'University of Amsterdam', 'description': 'Research project in spectroscopy of  biophysics:
 Swammerdam Institute for Life Science, department of Molecular cytology,University of Amsterdam. 
In this project, fluorescent molecules were used as an essential tool in the research aimed at the understanding of the biophysical properties of lipid rafts, which are functional microdomains in the biological membrane. These fluorescent probes are used to envisage a liquid ordered phase in a liquid disordered phase on a molecular scale. The investigation focused on the thermodynamic changes, in particular viscosity and transition temperature that accompanied the phase order of the lipid. To achieve this purpose, the probe should be able to respond to any perturbation in microviscosity of the surrounding. 
At the same time, the fluorescence techniques and all its relevant computational methods were the research main subject', 'title': 'Researcher Assistant', 'employment_type': None}]}]
